slides.title: The Management Process
content: Management involves planning, organizing, leading, and controlling resources. Managers must understand their environments and use all resources effectively.
Planning involves defining goals and developing a comprehensive strategy for achieving them. Plans must be achievable and flexible for unexpected events.
Organizing is the process of arranging activities and resources into a coherent structure. Organizational charts show job roles and reporting relationships.
Leading is the process of guiding and motivating employees to meet the firm’s goals. It requires effective communication and interpersonal skills.
Controlling is the process of monitoring the firm’s performance to make sure goals are being met. It involves establishing standards, measuring performance and taking action.
Management is a blend of both science and art, requiring rational analysis and intuitive judgment to solve problems effectively.
slides.script: Welcome to the chapter on 'Managing the Business'! In this first slide, we'll define management as a process involving four key functions: planning, organizing, leading, and controlling. Successful managers are those who can expertly navigate this process using a mix of logical reasoning and intuitive understanding. We'll discuss each of these components in more detail throughout the chapter.

slides.title: Types of Managers
content: Top managers (CEO) are responsible for the overall performance of the organization, focusing on strategy and external relations.
Middle managers (plant manager) implement strategies and work towards goals set by top managers, acting as a link between top and first line.
First-line managers (supervisors) supervise and oversee employees, focusing on day-to-day operations and ensuring compliance with policies.
Managers can also be classified by area, such as human resources, operations, marketing, information, and finance. Each require unique skillsets.
slides.script: This slide introduces the different types of managers found in an organization. We have top managers who set the strategic vision, middle managers who translate that vision into actionable plans, and first-line managers who oversee day-to-day operations. We also touched on functional areas of management which requires different skill sets.

slides.title: Managerial Roles and Skills
content: Managers fulfill interpersonal roles as figureheads, leaders, and liaisons, building relationships and representing the organization.
Informational roles involve monitoring information, disseminating it, and acting as spokespersons for the organization.
Decisional roles require managers to be entrepreneurs, disturbance handlers, resource allocators, and negotiators.
Technical skills enable managers to perform specialized tasks effectively, such as data analysis or code writing.
Human relations skills facilitate communication, understanding, and effective interpersonal interactions within the organization.
Conceptual skills involve the ability to think abstractly, analyze complex situations, and see the big picture.
slides.script: Now, let's move on to the roles and skills needed to be an effective manager. Managers wear many hats, from leading and motivating their teams to gathering and sharing information. They also need a blend of technical, interpersonal, and conceptual skills to succeed. This slide will discuss the key elements.

slides.title: More Managerial Skills
content: Diagnostic skills involve understanding problems and identifying the root causes to implement effective solutions.
Communication skills ensure information is clearly conveyed and understood by others, fostering collaboration.
Decision-making skills enable managers to select the best course of action, balancing logic and intuition.
Time management skills help managers use their time productively, prioritizing tasks and avoiding time-wasters.  It’s all about efficiency.
Global management skills are essential for operating in diverse international contexts, understanding cultural nuances.
Technology management skills are vital for leveraging IT tools and data to improve performance and decision-making.
slides.script: Continuing our discussion on essential skills, this slide highlights some more important managerial skills, including diagnostic, communication, decision-making, and time management. As businesses become increasingly global, managers also need to develop skills in global and technology management.

slides.title: Strategic Management: Setting Goals
content: Strategic management ensures an organization aligns effectively with its environment and is essential for long-term success.
Setting goals gives direction and guidance for managers, clarifies corporate culture, and facilitates resource allocation.
Goals provide a tangible way to assess overall organizational performance and implement necessary steps to achieve those goals.
Long-term goals (5+ years) relate to extended periods, intermediate goals (1-5 years) are set for a period, and short-term goals (1 year) for areas.
slides.script: This slide starts our focus on strategic management and its important role in setting business goals. Goal setting provides clear direction, supports strategic resource allocation, and shapes corporate culture.  This involves setting long-term, intermediate and short term goals.

slides.title: Formulating Strategy
content: Corporate strategy decides the businesses a company will own, using growth or retrenchment approaches to define scope.
Business strategy (competitive) takes place at the business unit level, focusing on improving the company's market position. Be competitive.
Functional strategy at the management level, manages marketing, finance, and operations activities effectively.
SWOT analysis is a framework for assessing organizational strengths, weaknesses, and environmental opportunities and threats.
slides.script: Building on the previous slide, now let's consider how strategy is formulated.  Three levels of strategy exist: corporate, business or competitive, and functional.  SWOT analysis is a useful tool for understanding a company's internal capabilities relative to its external environment.  Here’s how it can help you in your business plans.

slides.title: Hierarchy of Plans
content: Strategic plans are made by top management and reflect decisions on resource allocation and steps to meet strategic goals.
Tactical plans are shorter-term, often by upper and middle management, and implement specific aspects of the company's strategic plans.
Operational plans, often developed by mid-level and lower-level managers, set short-term targets for daily, weekly, or monthly performance.
The levels constitute a hierarchy because implementing is practical when a logical flow exists from level to level.
slides.script: Once strategies are defined, the next step is creating a hierarchy of plans. These include strategic plans, which outline broad, long-term objectives; tactical plans, which focus on short-term implementation; and operational plans, which set targets for daily performance.

slides.title: Contingency Planning
content: Contingency planning identifies potential aspects of a business or market that might change and establishes a company’s course of action.
Unexpected crises can also create significant challenges, so companies engage in crisis management, preparing for emergencies.
Risk avoidance can be implemented by purchasing activities from the outside and risk control can minimize the frequency or severity of loss.
Reserve funds can be set aside to implement risk retention and insurance is a form of risk transfer to another firm.
slides.script: Even the best-laid plans can go awry, so it's important to plan for the unexpected. Contingency planning involves identifying potential changes and establishing response plans. Risk management can be implemented by purchasing activities from the outside.

slides.title: Corporate Culture
content: Corporate culture reflects the shared experiences, stories, beliefs, and norms that characterize the organization.
A strong corporate culture can be vital to the organization as it directs employee efforts and helps employees work toward the same goals.
Companies also use training and orientation to transmit their culture to others in the organization.
Companies are looking to change their cultures by focusing on customers and looking at what competitors are doing.
slides.script: Finally, this chapter examines the role of corporate culture. A strong culture helps align employee efforts and guides behavior, which can be achieved through effective communication, training and by rewarding those who understand the company culture.
